PROFESSOR: The other piece
of teaching is giving talks.

I'm not so sure I refer
to them as lectures, but really talks about work. I bring in my own work that
I've done in the form of slides,

often, to explain particular
ideas about architecture.

Although there is no
great knowledge that can be passed on,
there are some ideas that you learn over the
years that you can pass on.

And the talks are a
way of doing that. Today's talk about the
space between buildings

is a topic that interests
me, and is very important for this particular project.

So what you're about to
see is a typical slide talk of which there are
also, usually, about 10

during the semester
on different subjects. At MIT, I teach studios,
which obviously, this is one.

But we also have a
very unique thing, which are workshops, which I'm
trying to actually make more

available for undergraduates. And in the workshop,
we explore topics

that we couldn't
normally do in the studio as a collective kind of group. And I just came back from
my meeting with my workshop

on what is known as
the "Space Within," which is an
interesting workshop. There are two kinds of
workshops that I teach.

And I will show you
samples of both. One is international
workshops where,

with engineers and planners,
we go to some place like Turkey or Honduras, Bhutan, India, and
do an actual project working

with different disciplines. And I'm supposed
to go to Turkey, is related to that workshop.

And there's probably 10
countries that we've worked in. So that's one form, which
is exposing students

to other cultures, but also
exposing you to other cultures, such as planners, and
engineers, and other people

at the Institute, and the
notion being that architecture gets richer when you have that.

The second kind of workshop is
this, which is exploring ideas that normally you
can't do in a studio,

but basically eventually may
influence the studio teaching.

So this is the space
between workshops, which I have done several of,
and there's a publication I'm

going to give you. And it suggests a
way of thinking. Now, by the way, I think that
the idea of a teacher for me

is one who practices
architecture, that I do, and does--

I will not call it
research, but searching for ideas that influence both
the practice and the teaching.

So all three of
them are related. I couldn't teach
without practicing. I couldn't practice teaching.

I couldn't search
without teaching. The trick is to do all three
at the same time, which is not

always easy, but somehow it
happens, or most of the time

it happens.  For some time, I
have been interested

in the issue of space. We all talk about
it, often referred to

as "negative space,"
"leftover space." I would like to think
about it as positive space,

and in this project
particularly, sensitize you to the
notion of making space

as opposed to making objects. We have, historically,
always been making objects,

without much regard to the
space between the objects. That is to say, you make your
object, I make my object.

I don't care if it fits or not. This site that you
have in this project is such that space and object
almost has to be related.

And we talked about this
a little bit yesterday. So I show some images. I love, and I spend
hours, sketching.

I try to draw. This is on Block
Island, these objects.

But the more I do
it, the more I'm interested in the
tension that they create

and the space that they make. So this, for me, is a
piece of architecture--

that is, the space
between the objects. So my interest has shifted
from the object to the space

that they create. Now, I know this is a
reciprocal relationship and I'm turning
you on your head.

But what I'm trying
to do is see if we can think about
the nature of this, and define that as an
architectural building tool.

We've done very well with the
object, or better, let us say.

Next. So for me, the Forbidden
City in Beijing, China,

which is made up
of a huge place, and made up of paths and places,
which is the basis of this--

this street is not to
buildings, but it's a space

moving through, as an example. And by the way, the Chinese,
in a historical sense,

understood the notion
of space better than any other civilization,
and they designed this space.

Next. Or in the case of
Siena, the space

of the streets, which
are paths, in this case leads to a place, which is the--

I hope I have a
slide of it, which is the greatest space
in the world-- the Campo and the tower, which
accents the Campo.

And the two work together. And by the way, a
tower in the space

is an object that I say is
the controller of space,

that is, you understand
the space because of it. Take it away with your mind,
and there's no space there.

That draws your attention to it. So church steeples,
towers, et cetera,

are ways, in my way of
thinking, of activating space. The Pyramid is not
an object in my mind,

but it's actually a recognition
of space around it-- just a slight twist.

Next.  So then the question is,
how can we think about this?

And I've tried to study that. I don't if you can
focus that any better. No?

Try it manually.  If we think about
the woods, a woods--
maybe out of focus--  it's not a bad picture.

It's a very good picture. I took it, but I don't know
what's wrong with this. I know what's wrong. Never mind, it's digitized,
and then it went bad.

If you think about
a woods, you have trees, which is meaningless
unless you can experience it.

This is like a
building, in my opinion. So we have to find a way
of experiencing the woods.

So that's the beginning
of understanding space. Next.

So the first definition
for me of space is a path that moves
through the woods.

That is to say that as we
move, we create a path.
And a door for me--

that door is not
a door, but it's an echo of a person
moving through space.

And that's why it's
6' 8" by 2' 10", because that's the
size of the body.

It's always related to the body. So therefore, the
first parameter

for me of understanding
the space between is understanding paths.

So in the woods, we
wouldn't know this was here unless we had the path.

Now, in our environment of
MIT, we don't have any paths,

we have highways. The Infinite Corridor
is the I-95 of paths.

And except for-- which is very
exciting-- at the end of it now, where they've opened
it up and you can look in,

you have no idea
what's going on. You're just speeding along. If anybody stops, there's
a major traffic jam there.

I was trying to
pass somebody and I felt as though I needed to
have a blinker light to be able to do it in there, and make
sure no one was coming forward.

So we don't understand
that notion. But paths are the most
beautiful beginning

of understanding space. And I don't care if this
is the design of the city, or your building, or a house.

It's the same notion-- that is, it can be
made up of paths, which are not circulation
as we think of it,

but there are places where the
people are, the good stuff. Next.

So this is the very basic
path on Block Island. It's been worn slightly.

If you look
carefully, you'll find what I call the "decoration
of architecture."

Certain flowers and plants
will start to bloom along it because the light hits it.

And it's a way of experiencing
the trees or the building. It's the same thing.

Next. It's the good stuff. Here's a very beautiful one in
Japan, which is very subtle,

but a path that's moving through
the woods in such a way that is, if you wish, making me
aware of trees in the space.

It's through that path
that I understand the place as it moves through. And by the way,
it looks natural.

It's not. It's all built. It's the same
old issue of what's Nature and what isn't. Next.

Or just the space between may
have been in the North End-- it is in the North End--

between two buildings acts as a
space that can focus something,
in this case buildings. And we have those on our site. Next.

Sometime-- and my hope
is in your building--

the path becomes a major
part of the building. And this was what I call the
public framework of paths.

This is in Berkeley. And this is the old
School of Architecture called the Ark Building. The exciting thing is that the
architectural school went up

the side of the hill
on the south side of a courtyard, several
courtyards, these steps.

And the studios were off
of these at various levels. And so this was the place
where everybody met.

And you would bump into
people between the courtyard and the studio-- quite different than
what we have here.

So the good stuff was not the
studio, but it was the path.

It was the actual
movement through. So you might think of
your building this way.

Next. Well, it's obvious, then, if we
have paths which are movement,

then we have places
which are non-movement. We have a place here,
kind of an executive

place here, this table. Sit around, the board
members, et cetera. But nevertheless, we're making
a place in the spaces here,

and all of you are
controlling the space. She's a little bit out of it. It doesn't quite make
it, but still, we

have something of a place. So the place is the second way
of defining the space between.

Therefore, in our
buildings, places in the building that we can
define are the good things.

That's where people
come together. In the woods, it's
where the sun is. And so you are
drawn towards that

like a moth towards a light. Next. Well, the Chinese
water gardens are

wonderful at making these
places, which actually also

involved every element
of architecture-- the ground, the in between,
the sky, the trees, the water,

the people. It's all one thing. You can't focus on a piece
of architecture there. It's a total experience.

Next-- which is a place-- next-- which has a
path in this case.

Ah, the Campo. Anybody been to the Campo?  It is, in my opinion--
the Campo is in Siena.

I'll tell you just
quickly the story. There were three
villages around Siena,

or in Siena, I should say. They were having little fights. And during the
Renaissance, they said,

let's build one place
that will celebrate the three, which was in between
the three in the valley.

And it became this great
living room, if you wish,

of not only Siena, but of the
world, or certainly of Italy, which is activated by
all kinds of activities--

commercial, major events. But you can go there any
time of the day or night,
and something will happen. Something is taking place. It's a living room for people.

We've talked a
little bit about that in terms of some of the
things you're doing, making living rooms outside
living rooms of community

spaces. This is one. And frankly, I don't know of one
that's any better in the world than this in terms of
proportion related to it.

It's almost a half circle. It's sloped slightly. There's a fountain here
that water runs through.

Campers will camp out on it. People will sing on it. There are coffee
shops, et cetera.

Next. And one a year is the
Palio, the great horse race

that I attended
several times, which only takes, I think 90 seconds. At that point, the living
room is transformed

into a place for people. These are seats. And all these are seats, as
you can see-- people all over.

And 40,000 or 50,000 people
will be in the middle. And you can see that
there's a track that

runs around it for a horse race
that I think takes 90 seconds. And the intention is that
each neighborhood has a horse

and they're betting
on it to win. For 90 seconds, the
horse race takes place.

There's a winner. And then there's
all kinds of fights because the horse race
has been fixed purposely.

Because at that point
in Italian history, they recognized that
there will always be war. So that's our one
day of it, as opposed
to what's going on now-- brilliant, in a way. Gets your aggressions out.

And when I lived
there one year, I was living in the
snail community.

And I had a badge. And I got mixed up into
the elephant community, and all of a sudden I
found myself in a fight.

And I had no idea
why I was being hit, but I was, because I was the
wrong person, which was fine. I shouldn't have been there.

But it's an incredible
event to come together. Yes. STUDENT: Oh, I
[INAUDIBLE] we could

get to a testing program
that leads a caterpillar. PROFESSOR: Oh, OK. STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE] what?

PROFESSOR: Caterpillar--
it's another neighborhood. STUDENT: Yeah, and they're-- PROFESSOR: No animals are-- STUDENT: So continues to email
me the updates on every race.

PROFESSOR: Oh, really? STUDENT: All the play
by play of the race. It's really fun, but--

PROFESSOR: You
didn't see the race? STUDENT: No, I didn't see it. I wasn't there to-- PROFESSOR: It's one of the
most incredible events to see,

these horses going around
this for 90 seconds. But to me, it's the highest
form of civilization,

and the highest form of a
community center that we have, the Siena Campo.

It's a space. It's not a bunch of objects. And it's a place where
people will come.

And by the way, some
of you are hinting towards this in what you're
doing in our project,

in a smaller scale. Next. OK, so now my study has
been to try to understand

how we might classify space. One of the problems
with our profession

is that we don't have
a knowledge base. I can't pass out
knowledge as I could

if I were a doctor or a lawyer. We really haven't
built a knowledge base, which we need to do.

Well, if you were a doctor,
there's a medical school. You would get case
studies of the past, which

has led us to where we are now. Because you're standing on the
shoulders of some other doctor

previously. In architecture, we
don't do that as much.

Because we have an
emphasis on creativity, I think, which is fine. But I think we could have
more of a knowledge base

that we could pass on. And what I'm attempting
to do in space to see is, can we build a knowledge
base that we can pass on.

So how to do that? So I started some time ago with
trying to understand a space. This is Louisburg Square.
Everybody know it? In Beacon Hill. STUDENT: What's that? PROFESSOR: Louisburg square.
Don't know? I don't know.

Well, go to Beacon
Hill and walk around. It's interesting
in the north end. This is the square in it--

little precious now. It's got a fence. You can't go in unless
you've got a key, but nevertheless, it's a space.

This is a typical
way of looking at it from an architectural
point of view-- objects.

And then the space is
vacant, left over, negative. Next.

So the first
exercise that I did-- and this is the very first one-- was trying to understand if
I could categorize the space

in terms of paths and places. And in this case,
the clear Plexiglas

was showing the paths
in different ways. And the gray area was
showing the place.

But even in the place,
there are paths. And then finally, the
blue was the inside paths

of the house, which to my
opinion is public in a house. Everything is either
public or private

depending on its proportion. So in a house as an
example, the stairs are public to
everybody in the house.

The living room is a
place that's public. So the blue was showing what
goes on inside and what you

don't-- and this is the
backyard, which is space. So in this case, I've just
turned the world upside down.

What you don't see
is the objects. And what you do
see is the space. And from the study
of this, I could

understand that space is
made up of several things. One is always the body,
the size of the body.

And the second is the size of
the house, which is related also to the size of the body. So there's some proportions
there that relate.

Next. We then did studies of
one semester on paths.

So these are paths
that we analyzed around Boston, the space of
the path, a street, perhaps.

Again, what you don't see are
buildings, but what you do see are the colors representing
different varieties of space outside.

Not all space is neutral,
nor is all space the same. In fact, now we're
working on space within,

which is a space
within a concert hall. And we've classified
12 kinds of space--

everything from what we
call "hot space," which is the seat right
next to the orchestra, the intimate space, which is
a space way in the back where

you can hide, soaring space,
which is in the center, et cetera. So we tried to understand
the different kinds of layers

of space that is created. Next. There's some more streets,
the clear being the street.

Each student would represent
slightly different in the way that they were talking
about the space.

Next. And still another
one, not obviously as contained as the first
one, as you can see.

This is Mass Avenue, actually. Next.  And this is Charlestown,
on a hill, and the street,

and how spaces are
acting off of that. You don't see any
buildings here.

Next.  If we are talking
about space, we

have to talk about new
ways of representing it. This was hand drawn, and now
we're working on digital.

But the white is space, and
what you don't see back in here

is the object. So these are different kinds
of outdoor, private spaces connected to the white
space which is public.

So you have transitional space
and very private space outside. Think about that again in
relationship to this notion

that I've introduced
of transitions from the inside the outside. There are different kinds of
space from one to the next.

Next. The same is true in
drawing of a section.

This is a section of space. The kinds of space that
you find at the bottom

is different than the
kinds of space at the top. This is the sky, and then
there's a building around that.

It's just turning
it upside down, just making you
think differently.

Next.  These are, then,
analyses of places.

This is Harvard
Square, trying to show the forces of Harvard Square
producing different kinds

of places and spaces. Plexiglas, by the way, was a
good material because it's--

I call it "frozen space" because
you could see it through it, and still acted as an object. Next.

Another one-- an intersection
of two streets making a place.

Next.  This is, in fact, Harvard
Square Brattle Theater

complex, which is interesting. You know Brattle Theater
area, the paths and places?

It's one of our more interesting
places, I think, to be, which is made up of paths
and places, but space as you

move through it. Next.  And still another
one-- oh, sorry.

Then-- let's see
what the next one is. OK, let's go back.
This is still a--  thank you.

This is Harvard's Holyoke Center
Place, and part of the path,

trying to show the intensity. Holyoke, you know that place? One of the most active
places in Harvard Square

most of the time. So place, space, and
activity of people

are also interconnected,
as was pointed out the other day by
Sara in relationship

to William White's work. Next-- which, by the way,
influenced this work.

We also tried to
see ways that we could photograph, or
document, or understand space.

So you don't have the
normal kind of photographs. These composite photographs
started to show space

a little bit more. Next. All these were experimental. There's Holyoke,
where you kind of get

the feeling of the space,
which is not easy to capture. We talk about space
as architects, but we don't know exactly what
it is, how to represent it,

certainly not in the
form of section and plans that are the usual
things that we do. Next.

So then, that led
to a design problem that you see here, where
people were designing
pieces of a larger community-- only space. Next.

And that ended up with
this basic community, again, of designing
the space first,

and then we fill in the objects. There was a program, of
course, but we purposely

did not work on objects. This is exactly what I'm
doing this term with the Space Within. We're designing a
concert hall, but we're

designing only the
space of the hall, not the exterior form,
although obviously, it's going to influence it.

Next. More detail of that. Next. That led to a set of
conclusions that you see here

in sections about the
different kinds of space that you might have in an area--

light space, private
space, et cetera, transitional space that makes
up, then, a neighborhood.

Next. All space is not equal. And then finally came
out to this notion of plan zones of transitional
space between the inside

and the outside. This is in Puerto
Rico, actually, where there's a
courtyard space inside.

So you could start to
define a body of knowledge about the kinds of spaces that
make up a piece of architecture
or an area of space. Next. And in section, the same--

a space that moves
through a house. This is very private. This is the public
stairs of the house.

Next. And then again, design spaces,
in this case, the Cavalieri

of Puerto Rico, by
using photo montages and drawing at the same time
to try to represent what

it is that we're designing. Next. And then the final
design, which came about.

You see objects here, but they
really came about from a space, so the white is the most public
and the yellow is most private,

but the black thing
is the objects. Next.

And then the
project that you saw in my office, which was the
redesign of Mission Hill. And there's two ways of
representing space, which

I'm still experimenting with. This one is intensity
of activity, which has to do not only with
physical form, but people

using it as in William White. And therefore, this area
I predicted or hoped

would be the most
intense as opposed to this, which would
be less intense. Next.

Next. And this was a
backyard space, which was very small chunks of
space, very informal--

not nearly as
intense as the other. Next.

And then projects
that people did-- on the left is a
space between model

of an area in the North End,
a different site, by the way. And on the right, then,
is a result of that.

You do the space first and
then the object second. Next.

Another one. Next.  And people have done over
the years, different ways--

no it's not, different site. But you'll find, in
this case, solid blocks
are of space, not a building. Next.
Another one-- next-- always space, always space.

So these are balconies
off of something, which are in between
an object and what you

don't see here, which is the-- I'm sorry, in between
the space and the object that you don't see here.

Next. And this end was
an exercise where--

I think, I hope-- the next
slide, a set of buildings, were programmed.

But we started with
designing with Plexiglas. By the way, what's
not shown here

is a set of proportion
of space blocks based on the human being of
sizes that you could work with.

So this is like a set
of Froebel blocks, but instead of being
positive, they're negative,
so you could build with them. Next. And out of that--

go back, if you can-- you do this first,
and then next, you

do the object, which is
resultant of studying the space.

You get that? It's just twisting it. Go back and forth. The first shot at it, the
space, the kind of thing

that the person
wanted in the space. And then that's the translation
of that into an object.

Just turns the world upside down
because what architects usually do is when they're done with
the space, they throw, as I say,

trees at it, and benches,
and cars, and people. And they say, oh, it's
going to be active. But it isn't.

It's usually horrible. So I'm attempting to make the
space the more important thing and the building second.

Now in reality, of course,
it's both is needed. But it takes one trip up
Route 1 North to understand

what I'm talking
about, when you find Dunkin' Donuts, and
that funny boat,

and all these little individual
actions with no relationship

to each other, which has
cluttered up our landscape. Or Shanghai, where everybody
is competing with everyone

to make objects
of great interest, but no relationship
to each other.
STUDENT: Like Vegas. PROFESSOR: Sorry? STUDENT: Is Vegas the same way? PROFESSOR: Oh, God, Vegas is--

that's what makes
Vegas what it is. And that is another--

Vegas is nothing but a
big billboard, of course. So they're purposely doing that. There is no space in Vegas,
which is kind of interesting.
It's all objects. Next. And that's it.

So I would like-- just wanted
to introduce that to you because in this project,
because of that site--

and we talked about that
yesterday a little bit-- you can't design this
without thinking about space.

The two have to come together. And we talked yesterday
about the spaces that came to an angle.
Who was it, Felix, which-- STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE].

PROFESSOR: It was you? OK. Well, and the dead cat
space, the leftover space
that nobody wants to be in. That was you.

That's what I want
you not to do. I want you to think
about the space simultaneously with the
design of the object.
